nodes.text: NOTES ON THE STARLIKE LOG–HARMONIC MAPPINGS OF
ORDER ALPHA
R. KARGAR AND H. MAHZOON
Abstract. Let h and g be two analytic functions in the unit disc ∆ that
g(0) = 1. Also let β be a complex number with Re{β } > −1/2. A function f
is said to be log–harmonic mapping if it has the following representation
f (z) = z|z |2β h(z)g (z) (z ∈ ∆).
A log–harmonic mapping f is said to b e starlike log–harmonic mapping of
order α, where 0 ≤ α < 1, if
Re (cid:26) zfz − zfz f (cid:27) > α (z ∈ ∆).
In this pap er, by use of the subordination principle, we study some geometric
properties of the starlike log–harmonic mappings of order α. Also, we estimate
the Jacobian of log–harmonic mappings.
1. Introduction
Let H(∆) b e the family of all analytic functions in the open unit disc ∆ :=
{z : |z| < 1}. Let f and g be two memb ers of the class H(∆) which satisfy the
normalized conditions f (0) = 0 = f ′ (0) − 1 and g (0) = 0 = g ′(0) − 1. We say that
a function f is sub ordinate to g, written f (z) ≺ g(z) or f ≺ g , if there exists an
analytic function ψ, known as a Schwarz function, with ψ (0) = 0 and |ψ(z)| ≤ |z |
such that f (z) = g (ψ(z)) for all z ∈ ∆. The set of all univalent (one–to–one)
functions f in ∆ is denoted by U . Furthermore, if g ∈ U in ∆, then we have the
following equivalence relation
Also let B(∆) denote the set of all functions w ∈ H(∆) satisfying |w(z )| < 1 in ∆.
A mapping f is said to be log–harmonic in ∆, if there exists an analytic function
w ∈ B (∆) such that f is a solution of the nonlinear elliptic partial differential
equation
(1.1) fz f = w (z ) fz f ,
where w is the second complex dilatation of f and w ∈ B(∆). We note that if f is
a non–vanishing log–harmonic mapping, then f has the following form
f (z) = h(z)g(z),
where b oth h and g are non–vanishing analytic functions, and that if f vanishes
at z = 0 but is not identically zero, then f has the following form

Key words and phrases. starlike log–harmonic mappings; log–harmonic mappings; subordina-
tion; Jacobian; real part.
R. KARGAR AND H. MAHZOON

class of functions of this form has been studied extensively by many works, see for
example [1]– [6] and [9].

Since w ∈ B(∆), thus Jf (z) > 0 and all non–constant log–harmonic mappings are
sense–preserving and open in the disc ∆.
Let f (z ) = z|z|2βh(z)g(z), where h(0) = g(0) = 1, be a log–harmonic mapping.
Then we say that f is a starlike log–harmonic (S LH) mapping of order α, where
(1.4) ∂∂ θ arg f (cid:0)reiθ (cid:1) = Re (cid:26) zfz − z fzf (cid:27) > α (z ∈ ∆).
We denote by S ∗LH(α), the set of all starlike log–harmonic mappings of order α.
The following lemma will be useful.
Lemma 1.1. [8, p. 35] Let Ξ be a simply connected domain in the complex plane
C, Ξ ̸= C and let b be a complex number with Re{b} > 0. Suppose that a function
ψ : C2 × ∆ → C satisfies the condition
ψ(iρ, σ; z) ̸∈ Ξ
for all real ρ, σ ≤ − | b − iρ |2 /(2Re{b}) and all z ∈ ∆. If the function p(z ) defined
by p(z ) = b + b1z + b2z2 + · · · is analytic in ∆ and if
ψ(p(z), zp′(z); z) ∈ Ξ,
then Re{p(z)} > 0 in ∆.
STARLIKE LOG–HARMONIC FUNCTIONS
One of the goals of this paper is to investigate some geometric prop erties of the
starlike log–harmonic mappings of order α, another is to give an estimate for the
Jacobian of log–harmonic mappings of the form (1.2).
2. Main Results
In the first result, by use of the sub ordination principle, we give a necessary and
sufficient condition for functions of the form (1.2) belonging to the class S ∗LH(α).
Theorem 2.1. Let α ∈ [0, 1) and Re{β } > −1/2. Then the function f (z ) =
z |z |2β h(z )g (z) belongs to the class S ∗LH(α) if, and only if,
